IronWASP Security Analysis Report
Report based on the analysis performed by the open source web security software, IronWASP
Overview
Index
http://127.0.0.1/
Overview
This report contains the list of security findings discovered by IronWASP. The current section of the report gives a brief overview of the number of different findings, the numbers are categorized by the hosts they were discovered on.
The index section contains the names of all the findings. The sections after that show details of every individual finding.

The table below shows the number of findings discovered in each host. The findings are seperated based on their type and severity.


Legend:

High     High Severity Vulnerability
Medium     Medium Severity Vulnerability
Low     Low Severity Vulnerability
Info     Information Findings
Test Leads     Things of interest for manual testing

The High, Medium and Low severity vulnerability numbers are also split based on the confidence with which IronWASP has reported them.

  0      High Confidence                0      Medium Confidence                0      Low Confidence             

High Medium Low Info Test leads Total Hosts

9
1
2
1
250
http://127.0.0.1/
135
100
2
2

0
1
0
0
Index
The titles of all the findings are listed below categorized by the host they were discovered on. All items in the list below are links to relevant sections in the report.

This response contains an HTML tag named 'h' with attribute name 'xex' and attribute value 'yey'. This was inserted by the payload.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2023 15:47:39 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 24314

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]>

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=about
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../about
Payload B - aa../about
Payload C - bb/../about
Payload D - bb../about

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file about by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file about normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file about inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=aa%2f..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the about file. The payload is aa../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=aa..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb/../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=bb%2f..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the about file. The payload is bb../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=bb..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\about
Payload B - aa..\about
Payload C - bb\..\about
Payload D - bb..\about

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file about by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file about normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file about inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa\..\about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=aa%5c..%5cabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the about file. The payload is aa..\about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=aa..%5cabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb\..\about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=bb%5c..%5cabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the about file. The payload is bb..\about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=bb..%5cabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=view_categories
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../view_categories
Payload B - aa../view_categories
Payload C - bb/../view_categories
Payload D - bb../view_categories

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file view_categories by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file view_categories normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file view_categories inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the view_categories file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../view_categories

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=aa%2f..%2fview_categories HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the view_categories file. The payload is aa../view_categories

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=aa..%2fview_categories HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the view_categories file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb/../view_categories

Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm

Payload B - aa..\view_categories
Payload C - bb\..\view_categories
Payload D - bb..\view_categories

They both refer to the file view_categories by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file view_categories normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file view_categories inside invalid directories (aa & bb).

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.

You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.

Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?p=about
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../about
Payload B - aa../about
Payload C - bb/../about
Payload D - bb../about

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file about by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file about normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file about inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?p=aa%2f..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the about file. The payload is aa../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?p=aa..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb/../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?p=bb%2f..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the about file. The payload is bb../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?p=bb..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\about
Payload B - aa..\about
Payload C - bb\..\about
Payload D - bb..\about

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file about by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file about normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file about inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa\..\about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?p=aa%5c..%5cabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?p=view_categories
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../view_categories
Payload B - aa../view_categories
Payload C - bb/../view_categories
Payload D - bb../view_categories

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file view_categories by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file view_categories normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file view_categories inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the view_categories file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../view_categories

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?p=aa%2f..%2fview_categories HTTP/1.1

Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the view_categories file. The payload is aa../view_categories

You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../view_product
Payload B - aa../view_product
Payload C - bb/../view_product
Payload D - bb../view_product

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file view_product by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file view_product normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file view_product inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the view_product file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../view_product

Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../products
Payload B - aa../products
Payload C - bb/../products
Payload D - bb../products

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file products by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file products normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file products inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the products file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../products

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=aa%2f..%2fproducts&c=eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the products file. The payload is aa../products

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=aa..%2fproducts&c=eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the products file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb/../products

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=bb%2f..%2fproducts&c=eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the products file. The payload is bb../products

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=bb..%2fproducts&c=eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\products
Payload B - aa..\products
Payload C - bb\..\products
Payload D - bb..\products

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file products by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file products normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file products inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../view_product
Payload B - aa../view_product
Payload C - bb/../view_product
Payload D - bb../view_product

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file view_product by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file view_product normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file view_product inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the view_product file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../view_product

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=aa%2f..%2fview_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the view_product file. The payload is aa../view_product

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=aa..%2fview_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\view_product
Payload B - aa..\view_product
Payload C - bb\..\view_product
Payload D - bb..\view_product

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file view_product by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file view_product normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file view_product inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../products
Payload B - aa../products
Payload C - bb/../products
Payload D - bb../products

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file products by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file products normally.

False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Reason 1:

Payload B - aa../view_product

Payload D - bb../view_product

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file view_product by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file view_product normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file view_product inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the view_product file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../view_product

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=aa%2f..%2fview_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the view_product file. The payload is aa../view_product

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=aa..%2fview_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

This payload refers to the view_product file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb/../view_product

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=bb%2f..%2fview_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the view_product file. The payload is bb../view_product

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=bb..%2fview_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\view_product
Payload B - aa..\view_product
Payload C - bb\..\view_product
Payload D - bb..\view_product

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file view_product by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file view_product normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file view_product inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../products
Payload B - aa../products
Payload C - bb/../products
Payload D - bb../products

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file products by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file products normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file products inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the products file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../products

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=aa%2f..%2fproducts&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the products file. The payload is aa../products

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=aa..%2fproducts&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

This payload refers to the products file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb/../products

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\products
Payload B - aa..\products
Payload C - bb\..\products
Payload D - bb..\products

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file products by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file products normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file products inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=view_categories
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../view_categories
Payload B - aa../view_categories
Payload C - bb/../view_categories
Payload D - bb../view_categories

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file view_categories by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file view_categories normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file view_categories inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the view_categories file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../view_categories

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=about
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../about
Payload B - aa../about
Payload C - bb/../about
Payload D - bb../about

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file about by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file about normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file about inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=aa%2f..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the about file. The payload is aa../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=aa..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb/../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=bb%2f..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the about file. The payload is bb../about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=bb..%2fabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\about
Payload B - aa..\about
Payload C - bb\..\about
Payload D - bb..\about

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file about by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file about normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file about inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa\..\about

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=aa%5c..%5cabout HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

This payload refers to the about file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb\..\about

Host: 127.0.0.1

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:price
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the price parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../31,349.00
Payload B - aa../31,349.00
Payload C - bb/../31,349.00
Payload D - bb../31,349.00

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file 31,349.00 by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file 31,349.00 normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file 31,349.00 inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the 31,349.00 file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../31,349.00

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=aa%2f..%2f31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the 31,349.00 file. The payload is aa../31,349.00

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=aa..%2f31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:inventory_id
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the inventory_id parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\1
Payload B - aa..\1
Payload C - bb\..\1
Payload D - bb..\1

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file 1 by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file 1 normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file 1 inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../view_product
Payload B - aa../view_product
Payload C - bb/../view_product
Payload D - bb../view_product

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file view_product by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file view_product normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file view_product inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
