Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 't'='t which evaluates to true. The payload is c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b' and 't'='t

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?p=view_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b'+and+'t'%3d't HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 't'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b' and 't'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?p=view_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b'+and+'t'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Reason 6:
IronWASP sent ' or sleep(5)# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 19195 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 26 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is ' or sleep(5)#

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?p=view_product&id='+or+sleep(5)%23 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 19195 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Affected Parameter:c
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the c parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ' as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is '.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=' HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 04 Sep 2023 23:10:23 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near ''''' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-compute[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ¿'"( as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is ¿'"(.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=¿'"( HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 04 Sep 2023 23:10:23 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near '&quot;('' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-co[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 3:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c'||'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Payload B - c'+'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Payload C - c' '81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload B and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads A. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is Oracle. Since incase of Oracle database server Payloads B & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload A would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is c'||'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c'%7c%7c'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL and MySQL databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is c'+'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c'%2b'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is c' '81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c'+'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 's'='s
Payload B - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 's'='r
Payload C - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 't'='t
Payload D - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 's'='s which evaluates to true. The payload is c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 's'='s

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx'+or+'s'%3d's HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Reason 5:
IronWASP sent ' or sleep(5)# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 89708 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 116 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 124324 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 116 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:price
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the price parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - 9'||'9,999.00
Payload B - 9'+'9,999.00
Payload C - 9' '9,999.00
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload A and B were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads C. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is MySQL. Since incase of MySQL database server Payloads A & B would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload C would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is 9'||'9,999.00

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=9'%7c%7c'9%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is 9'+'9,999.00

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=9'%2b'9%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is 9' '9,999.00

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used Oracle and MS SQL databases' concatenation syntax.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:inventory_id
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the inventory_id parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - 1xxx" or "s"="s
Payload B - 1xxx" or "s"="r
Payload C - 1xxx" or "t"="t
Payload D - 1xxx" or "t"="r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition "s"="s which evaluates to true. The payload is 1xxx" or "s"="s

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition "s"="r which evaluates to false. The payload is 1xxx" or "s"="r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1xxx%22+or+%22s%22%3d%22r&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition "t"="t which evaluates to true. The payload is 1xxx" or "t"="t

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1xxx%22+or+%22t%22%3d%22t&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition "t"="r which evaluates to false. The payload is 1xxx" or "t"="r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1xxx%22+or+%22t%22%3d%22r&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent ";waitfor delay '0:0:5'-- as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45140 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 39 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is ";waitfor delay '0:0:5'--

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=%22%3bwaitfor+delay+'0%3a0%3a5'--&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 45140 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Affected Parameter:c
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the c parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ' as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is '.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=' HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 04 Sep 2023 23:10:25 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near ''''' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-compute[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ¿'"( as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is ¿'"(.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=¿'"( HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 04 Sep 2023 23:10:25 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near '&quot;('' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-co[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 3:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c'||'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Payload B - c'+'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Payload C - c' '4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads B. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is MS SQL. Since incase of MS SQL database server Payloads A & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload B would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is c'||'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c'%7c%7c'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is c'+'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c'%2b'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MySQL and Oracle databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is c' '4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c'+'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 's'='s
Payload B - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 's'='r
Payload C - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 't'='t
Payload D - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 's'='s which evaluates to true. The payload is c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 's'='s

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx'+or+'s'%3d's HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 's'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 's'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx'+or+'s'%3d'r HTTP/1.1

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 't'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 't'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx'+or+'t'%3d'r HTTP/1.1

Reason 5:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b' and 's'='s
Payload B - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b' and 's'='r
Payload C - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b' and 't'='t
Payload D - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b' and 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the AND keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Reason 6:
IronWASP sent ' or sleep(5)=' as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 98328 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 30 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is ' or sleep(5)='

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c='+or+sleep(5)%3d' HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 98328 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

Reason 7:
IronWASP sent ") or sleep(5)=" as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45145 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 30 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

SQL Injection Detected

Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3
Affected Parameter:c
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the c parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ' as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.

Date: Mon, 04 Sep 2023 23:10:23 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near '&quot;('' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-co[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 3:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - e'||'ccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3
Payload B - e'+'ccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3
Payload C - e' 'ccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads B. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is MS SQL. Since incase of MS SQL database server Payloads A & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload B would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is e'||'ccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=e'%7c%7c'ccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is e'+'ccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=e'%2b'ccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MySQL and Oracle databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is e' 'ccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=e'+'ccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx' or 's'='s
Payload B - eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx' or 's'='r
Payload C - eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx' or 't'='t
Payload D - eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx' or 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 's'='s which evaluates to true. The payload is eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx' or 's'='s

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx'+or+'s'%3d's HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 's'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx' or 's'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx'+or+'s'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 't'='t which evaluates to true. The payload is eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx' or 't'='t

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx'+or+'t'%3d't HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 't'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx' or 't'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3xxx'+or+'t'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Reason 5:
IronWASP sent " or sleep(5)# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 89700 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 65 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is " or sleep(5)#

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=%22+or+sleep(5)%23 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 89700 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

Reason 6:
IronWASP sent ' or sleep(5)=' as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45155 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 65 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is ' or sleep(5)='

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c='+or+sleep(5)%3d' HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 45155 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c
Affected Parameter:c
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the c parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ' as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is '.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c=' HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 04 Sep 2023 23:32:15 GMT

})
</script><br />

This is an indication of SQL Injection.

Payload B - a'+'87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c
Payload C - a' '87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c

Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload B and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads A. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is Oracle. And Payload A would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 's'='s
Payload B - a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 's'='r
Payload C - a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 't'='t
Payload D - a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:

If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Reason 5:
IronWASP sent ' or sleep(5)# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45169 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 61 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is ' or sleep(5)#

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c='+or+sleep(5)%23 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 45169 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 106209 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 61 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is ' or sleep(5)='

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././?p=products&c='+or+sleep(5)%3d' HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 106209 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:price
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the price parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - 3"||"1,349.00
Payload B - 3"+"1,349.00
Payload C - 3" "1,349.00
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload A and B were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads C. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is MySQL. Since incase of MySQL database server Payloads A & B would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload C would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is 3"||"1,349.00

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=3%22%7c%7c%221%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is 3"+"1,349.00

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=3%22%2b%221%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is 3" "1,349.00

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././.?price=3%22+%221%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used Oracle and MS SQL databases' concatenation syntax.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b&s=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Affected Parameter:c
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the c parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ' as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is '.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=products&c='&s=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 04 Sep 2023 23:41:48 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near ''''' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-compute[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ¿'"( as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is ¿'"(.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=products&c=¿'"(&s=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 04 Sep 2023 23:41:48 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near '&quot;('' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-co[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 3:
IronWASP sent ' or sleep(5)=' as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 89342 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 69 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is ' or sleep(5)='

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=products&c='+or+sleep(5)%3d'&s=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 89342 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

Parameter Location:Query
Description:

This is an indication of SQL Injection.

</script><br />

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c'||'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Payload B - c'+'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Payload C - c' '4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads B. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is MS SQL. Since incase of MS SQL database server Payloads A & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload B would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is c'||'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?p=products&c=c'%7c%7c'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b&s=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
