Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 's'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 's'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx'+or+'s'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 't'='t which evaluates to true. The payload is c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 't'='t

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx'+or+'t'%3d't HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 't'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 't'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx'+or+'t'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Reason 5:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c' and 's'='s
Payload B - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c' and 's'='r
Payload C - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c' and 't'='t
Payload D - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c' and 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the AND keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 's'='s which evaluates to true. The payload is c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c' and 's'='s

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c'+and+'s'%3d's HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 's'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c' and 's'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c'+and+'s'%3d'r HTTP/1.1

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c'+and+'t'%3d't HTTP/1.1

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 't'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c' and 't'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c'+and+'t'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Reason 6:
IronWASP sent 1 or sleep(5)# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 263404 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 125 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is 1 or sleep(5)#

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=1+or+sleep(5)%23 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 263404 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

Reason 7:
IronWASP sent " or sleep(5)=" as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 207245 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 125 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is " or sleep(5)="

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 207245 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

Reason 8:
IronWASP sent ' or sleep(5)=' as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 10257 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 125 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Affected Parameter:id
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the id parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ' as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is '.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id=' HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2023 15:02:05 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near ''''' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-compute[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ¿'"( as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is ¿'"(.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id=¿'"( HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2023 15:02:05 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near '&quot;('' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-co[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 3:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c'||'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Payload B - c'+'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Payload C - c' '81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads B. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is MS SQL. Since incase of MS SQL database server Payloads A & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload B would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is c'||'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id=c'%7c%7c'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is c'+'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id=c'%2b'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MySQL and Oracle databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is c' '81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id=c'+'81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 's'='s
Payload B - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 's'='r
Payload C - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 't'='t
Payload D - c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862cxxx' or 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 't'='t which evaluates to true. The payload is c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c' and 't'='t

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c'+and+'t'%3d't HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 't'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c' and 't'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c'+and+'t'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Reason 6:
IronWASP sent ' or sleep(5)=' as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 261400 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 136 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is ' or sleep(5)='

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id='+or+sleep(5)%3d' HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 261400 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:price
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the price parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent 1) and sleep(5)# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45114 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 240 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is 1) and sleep(5)#

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=1)+and+sleep(5)%23&inventory_id=1&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 45114 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ') and sleep(5)=' as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45142 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 240 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is ') and sleep(5)='

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Affected Parameter:c
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the c parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ' as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is '.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=' HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2023 15:47:37 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near ''''' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-compute[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ¿'"( as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is ¿'"(.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=¿'"( HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2023 15:47:38 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near '&quot;('' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-co[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 3:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c'||'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Payload B - c'+'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Payload C - c' '4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads B. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is MS SQL. Since incase of MS SQL database server Payloads A & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload B would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is c'||'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=c'%7c%7c'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is c'+'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=c'%2b'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MySQL and Oracle databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is c' '4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=c'+'4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 's'='s
Payload B - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 's'='r
Payload C - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 't'='t
Payload D - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 's'='s which evaluates to true. The payload is c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 's'='s

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx'+or+'s'%3d's HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 's'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 's'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx'+or+'s'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 't'='t which evaluates to true. The payload is c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 't'='t

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx'+or+'t'%3d't HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 't'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx' or 't'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849bxxx'+or+'t'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1

Reason 5:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b' and 's'='s
Payload B - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b' and 's'='r
Payload C - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b' and 't'='t
Payload D - c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b' and 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the AND keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Reason 6:
IronWASP sent ' or sleep(5)# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45176 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 282 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a SQL query snippet which if executed will cause a delay of 5000 milliseconds. The payload is ' or sleep(5)#

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c='+or+sleep(5)%23 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 45176 milliseconds to get this response. It took so long because of the 5000 milliseconds delay caused by the payload.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c
Affected Parameter:c
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the c parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ' as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is '.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=' HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2023 15:47:39 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near ''''' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-compute[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ¿'"( as payload to the application and the response that came back had the error message You have an error in your SQL syntax;. This error message is usually associated with SQL query related errors and it appears that the payload was able to break out of the data context and cause this error. This is an indication of SQL Injection.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the response received for the payload and confirm if the error message actually is because of some SQL related exception on the server-side. Try sending the same request without the payload and check if the error goes away.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is meant to trigger database error messages. The payload is ¿'"(.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=¿'"( HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Response from the Server:

This response contains database error messages.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2023 15:47:39 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
if(sTxt != '')
location.href = './?p=products&search='+sTxt;
})
</script><br />
<b>Fatal error</b>: Uncaught mysqli_sql_exception: You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near '&quot;('' at line 1 in C:\xampp\htdocs\3.online-co[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 3:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - a'||'87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c
Payload B - a'+'87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c
Payload C - a' '87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload B and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads A. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is Oracle. Since incase of Oracle database server Payloads B & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload A would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is a'||'87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=a'%7c%7c'87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL and MySQL databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is a'+'87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=a'%2b'87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is a' '87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=a'+'87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 's'='s
Payload B - a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 's'='r
Payload C - a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 't'='t
Payload D - a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 's'='s which evaluates to true. The payload is a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 's'='s

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx'+or+'s'%3d's HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 's'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 's'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx'+or+'s'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 't'='t which evaluates to true. The payload is a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 't'='t

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx'+or+'t'%3d't HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 't'='r which evaluates to false. The payload is a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx' or 't'='r

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?p=products&c=a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122cxxx'+or+'t'%3d'r HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Reason 5:
IronWASP sent sleep(5)# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of SQL code that will cause the database server to sleep for 5000 milliseconds. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45179 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 352 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected SQL code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:price
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the price parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - 3'||'1,349.00
Payload B - 3'+'1,349.00
Payload C - 3' '1,349.00
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload B and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads A. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is Oracle. Since incase of Oracle database server Payloads B & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload A would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is 3'||'1,349.00

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=3'%7c%7c'1%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL and MySQL databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is 3'+'1,349.00

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=3'%2b'1%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is 3' '1,349.00

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=3'+'1%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=rllrl1k5jtnk9qulpgithjbmbb



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Affected Parameter:id
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the id parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 90641 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 67 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?p=view_product&id=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 90641milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?search=bb
Affected Parameter:search
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the search parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 . If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 79344 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 92 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./?search=+%2fusr%2fsbin%2fping+-s+localhost+1000+6+ HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 79344milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent bb&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45192 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 92 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

It took 45192milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>

Severity:High

Affected Parameter:id
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the id parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 . If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45184 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 42 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/

Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the id parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b| /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 . If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 119124 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 69 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6

Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm

If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45125 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 69 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:

IronWASP sent | ping -c 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -c 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 168057 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 59 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.

To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -c 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././.?price=31%2c349.00+ping+-c+6+localhost&inventory_id=2&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 64316milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?search=pppp
Affected Parameter:search
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the search parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ; /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 . If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 29998 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 103 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?search=%3b+%2fusr%2fsbin%2fping+-s+localhost+1000+6+ HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 29998milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent run ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - run ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 64338 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 103 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: run ping -n 6 localhost

Host: 127.0.0.1

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection
