After the payload was injected the response from the application took 25145 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 85 milliseconds. Description:
Command Injection was identified in the id parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 19169 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 75 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.

If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -c 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././././?p=products+ping+-c+6+localhost&c=eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 54404milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent products&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 10163 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 38 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?search=oooo
Affected Parameter:search
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the search parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 . If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 69787 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 85 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?search=%26%26+%2fusr%2fsbin%2fping+-s+localhost+1000+6+ HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 69787milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent oooo&& ping -c 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -c 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 79410 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 85 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:price
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the price parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 . If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 69777 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 129 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?price=+%2fusr%2fsbin%2fping+-s+localhost+1000+6+&inventory_id=1&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 69777milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent 99,999.00 /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - /usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 1000 6 . If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 79454 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 129 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:inventory_id
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the inventory_id parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent | ping -c 17 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -c 17 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 17 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 16408 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 139077 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 8204 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 16408 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -c 17 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=%7c+ping+-c+17+localhost&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm

It took 139077milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 16408 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Code Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Affected Parameter:id
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Code Injection was identified in the id parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Code Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute code on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Code_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ';import time;time.sleep(5);# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of code - import time;time.sleep(5);. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45110 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 45 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a code snippet which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The code snippet is: import time;time.sleep(5);

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?p=view_product&id='%3bimport+time%3btime.sleep(5)%3b%23 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 45110 milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ";import time;time.sleep(5);# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of code - import time;time.sleep(5);. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 45122 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 45 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

Code Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute code on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Code_Injection

Reasons:

IronWASP sent ";import time;time.sleep(45); as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of code - import time;time.sleep(45);. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 45336 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 89679 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22668 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a code snippet which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 45336 milliseconds. The code snippet is: import time;time.sleep(45);

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?p=view_product&id=%22%3bimport+time%3btime.sleep(45)%3b HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 89679 milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 45336 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Code Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?p=view_product&id=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Code Injection was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Code Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute code on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Code_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent ';sleep(5);# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of code - sleep(5);. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 89684 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 61 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Request sent by Scanner:

Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 89684 milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 143193 milliseconds. Code Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././././?p=products&c=c81e728d9d4c2f636f067f89cc14862c
Affected Parameter:p
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Code Injection was identified in the p parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Code Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute code on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Code_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ";sleep(5);# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of code - sleep(5);. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 54414 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 118 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of seconds of delay to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 10216 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 118 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.

Code Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute code on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Code_Injection

Reasons:

IronWASP sent ";sleep(5);# as payload to the application. This payload has a small snippet of code - sleep(5);. If this code is executed then the application will return the response 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 69786 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 78 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected code snippet could have been executed on the server-side.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?price=31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=%22%3bsleep(5)%3b%23 HTTP/1.1

Server Side Request Forgery Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:quantity
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the quantity parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - localhost:65555
Payload B - localhost:65533
Payload C - localhost:66666
Payload D - localhost:65534

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to ports 65555 and 66666 on the server which are invalid ports.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They both refer to ports 65533 and 65534 on the server which are valid ports.
If the application is vulnerable to SSRF then it will try to connect to these ports and connections to invalid ports with throw an exception of different type than the exception or error caused by connecting to the valid ports 65533 and 65534 which are most likely to be closed.
This would mean that the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D.

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by chaning the port number to some other invalid port and change payloads B & D to some other valid port numbers and check of the four response show the same pattern as before.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 65555 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65555

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=localhost%3a65555 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65533 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65533

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=localhost%3a65533 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 66666 on localhost. The payload is localhost:66666

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=localhost%3a66666 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65534 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65534

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=31%2c349.00&inventory_id=2&quantity=localhost%3a65534 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Server Side Request Forgery Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:price
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the price parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - localhost:65555
Payload B - localhost:65533
Payload C - localhost:66666
Payload D - localhost:65534

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to ports 65555 and 66666 on the server which are invalid ports.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They both refer to ports 65533 and 65534 on the server which are valid ports.
If the application is vulnerable to SSRF then it will try to connect to these ports and connections to invalid ports with throw an exception of different type than the exception or error caused by connecting to the valid ports 65533 and 65534 which are most likely to be closed.
This would mean that the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D.

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by chaning the port number to some other invalid port and change payloads B & D to some other valid port numbers and check of the four response show the same pattern as before.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?price=localhost%3a66666&inventory_id=1&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1

Affected Parameter:search
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the search parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

This payload points to the valid port 65533 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65533

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?search=localhost%3a65533 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 66666 on localhost. The payload is localhost:66666

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?search=localhost%3a66666 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65534 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65534

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?search=localhost%3a65534 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Server Side Request Forgery Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:inventory_id
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the inventory_id parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - localhost:65555
Payload B - localhost:65533
Payload C - localhost:66666
Payload D - localhost:65534

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to ports 65555 and 66666 on the server which are invalid ports.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They both refer to ports 65533 and 65534 on the server which are valid ports.
If the application is vulnerable to SSRF then it will try to connect to these ports and connections to invalid ports with throw an exception of different type than the exception or error caused by connecting to the valid ports 65533 and 65534 which are most likely to be closed.
This would mean that the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D.

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by chaning the port number to some other invalid port and change payloads B & D to some other valid port numbers and check of the four response show the same pattern as before.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 65555 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65555

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=localhost%3a65555&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65533 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65533

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=localhost%3a65533&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 66666 on localhost. The payload is localhost:66666

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=localhost%3a66666&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65534 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65534

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=localhost%3a65534&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Server Side Request Forgery Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././?search=uuuuu
Affected Parameter:search
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the search parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - localhost:65555
Payload B - localhost:65533
Payload C - localhost:66666
Payload D - localhost:65534

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to ports 65555 and 66666 on the server which are invalid ports.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They both refer to ports 65533 and 65534 on the server which are valid ports.
If the application is vulnerable to SSRF then it will try to connect to these ports and connections to invalid ports with throw an exception of different type than the exception or error caused by connecting to the valid ports 65533 and 65534 which are most likely to be closed.
This would mean that the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D.

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by chaning the port number to some other invalid port and change payloads B & D to some other valid port numbers and check of the four response show the same pattern as before.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Confidence:Medium

Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the price parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

This payload points to the valid port 65533 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65533

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/./php-ocls/.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=localhost%3a65533&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

Information about the Response from the Server:

This payload points to the invalid port 66666 on localhost. The payload is localhost:66666

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/./php-ocls/.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=localhost%3a66666&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65534 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65534

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/./php-ocls/.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=localhost%3a65534&quantity=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Server Side Request Forgery Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././././?search=tttt
Affected Parameter:search
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the search parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - localhost:65555
Payload B - localhost:65533
Payload C - localhost:66666
Payload D - localhost:65534

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to ports 65555 and 66666 on the server which are invalid ports.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They both refer to ports 65533 and 65534 on the server which are valid ports.
If the application is vulnerable to SSRF then it will try to connect to these ports and connections to invalid ports with throw an exception of different type than the exception or error caused by connecting to the valid ports 65533 and 65534 which are most likely to be closed.
This would mean that the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D.

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by chaning the port number to some other invalid port and change payloads B & D to some other valid port numbers and check of the four response show the same pattern as before.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 65555 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65555

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././././?search=localhost%3a65555 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65533 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65533

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././././?search=localhost%3a65533 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 66666 on localhost. The payload is localhost:66666

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././././?search=localhost%3a66666 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65534 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65534

GET http://127.0.0.1/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/./././././?search=localhost%3a65534 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: PHPSESSID=ie1cuuk623jfd9d1fmu5bn38dm



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Server Side Request Forgery Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././././.?price=99%2c999.00&inventory_id=1&quantity=1
Affected Parameter:quantity
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the quantity parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - localhost:65555
Payload B - localhost:65533
Payload C - localhost:66666
Payload D - localhost:65534

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to ports 65555 and 66666 on the server which are invalid ports.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They both refer to ports 65533 and 65534 on the server which are valid ports.
If the application is vulnerable to SSRF then it will try to connect to these ports and connections to invalid ports with throw an exception of different type than the exception or error caused by connecting to the valid ports 65533 and 65534 which are most likely to be closed.
This would mean that the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D.

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by chaning the port number to some other invalid port and change payloads B & D to some other valid port numbers and check of the four response show the same pattern as before.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Server Side Request Forgery Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/.?search=xxxxx
Affected Parameter:search
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the search parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - localhost:65555
Payload B - localhost:65533
Payload C - localhost:66666
Payload D - localhost:65534

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to ports 65555 and 66666 on the server which are invalid ports.

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.

To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Cookie PHPSESSID missing the HttpOnly flag
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:High
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/
Description:
The HttpOnly flag was missing on the cookie: PHPSESSID. This may allow an attacker to get the cookie information using XSS attacks.
Analyzed Response:

The value of the cookie is not protected by HttpOnly flag and hence becomes accessible from JavaScript

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 04 Sep 2023 18:26:27 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Set-Cookie: PHPSESSID=0vq8nvkr5b9ag02uits40u0b8v; path=/
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 24300


Directory Listing at : /3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/./
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/./?p=view_categories
Description:
A directory listing vulnerability was found at /3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/./
A directory listing provides an attacker with the complete index of all the resources locatedinside of the directory. The specific risks and consequences vary dependingon which files are listed and accessible.
References:
CWE-548: Information Exposure Through Directory Listing
Analyzed Response:

Text found in this response body indicates that there is Directory Listing on the server

<tr><td valign="top"><img src="/icons/unknown.gif" alt="[ ]"></td><td><a [---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
SQL Error Messages Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1/
Affected Url:/3.online-computer-and-laptop-store/php-ocls/././?p=products&c=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b&s=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b
Affected Parameter:c
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Error Triggering was identified in the c parameter of the Query section of the scanned request. SQL Error Messages have been found in the response when testing this parameter. All checks performed to identify SQL Injection returned negative results so the reason for why these error messages appear cannot be determined.
The error messages are:
You have an error in your SQL syntax;
You have an error in your SQL syntax;
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check that discovered this issue are available below.
Response from the Server:
